21. Midline catheter tip position and catheter-related complications in antimicrobial therapy: A multi-center randomized controlled trial. Values highlighted: Reduced Complications | First-Attempt Insertion | Longer Dwell Time | Stability
(Zhao L et al. Int J Nurs Stud. 2023)
Study author(s)
Zhao L, Fan X, Zhao L, et al.
Study design (level of evidence)
Randomized controlled trial (Level 2)
Study objective
5
To provide evidence for selecting MC tip
positions for safe use in antimicrobial
therapy.
Publication
Int J Nurs Stud. 2023
DOI: 10.1016/j.ijnurstu.2023.104476
Study location
China
Study Length
5 months (September 2020 - January 2021)

Study protocol. Evaluation indicators and judgment criteria were
incidence of catheter-related complications and
indwelling catheter duration.
Study findings. Longest dwell time recorded was of 131 days.
Study findings. MC tips placed in the subclavian or axillary vein of the chest wall had the lowest complication rates.

Study findings. Placing midline catheter tips in the subclavian or axillary vein significantly reduces catheter-
related complications during antimicrobial therapy.

22. Comparing incidence of thrombosis in PICC and midlines and evaluating the role of anticoagulation, site of insertion, and risk factors. Values highlighted : Reduced Complications
(Zohourian H et al. J Assoc Vasc Access. 2019)
Study author(s)
Zohourian H, Schaubschlager T, Phan L,
et al.
Study design (level of evidence)
Retrospective cohort study (Level
Study objective
To evaluate previously proposed risk factors
associated with increased rate of CT and to
form an objective clinical prediction score to
aid clinicians in distinguishing high-risk
patients.
Publication
J Assoc Vasc Access. 2019
DOI: 10.1016/j.java.2018.29.004
Study location
United States
Study Length
1 year (January 1, 2016 - December 31, 2016)

Study protocol. Inclusion criteria: Adult patients who underwent
either a PICC or midline catheter placement
between January 1 and December 31, 2016.

Study protocol. The means or frequencies of potential catheter-
related thrombosis (CT) risk factors were compared
between cases and controls.
Study findings. The insertion site, whether basilic, brachial, or cephalic vein, did not significantly affect the risk of thrombosis.
Study findings. Prophylactic anticoagulation showed reduced CT trend but was not statistically significant.

Study findings. Identified risk factors are associated with increased rate of thrombosis. A clinical prediction score
can objectively identify high risk patients. There was no statistical difference in thrombosis event
between vein insertion sites or use of prophylactic anticoagulation.

Study findings. Midline catheters demonstrated a slightly lower, though not statistically significant,
incidence of thrombosis compared to PICCs, with several patient and device factors
influencing CT risk.

23. Midline venous catheters as an alternative to central line catheter placement: a product evaluation. Values highlighted : Reduced Complications | First-Attempt Insertion | Longer Dwell Time | Stability|
Cost Effective
(Car A et al. Br J Nurs. 2021)
Study author(s)
Carr A, Green JR, Benish E, et al.
3
Study design (level of evidence)
Prospective observational study
(Level 3)
Study objective
To evaluate the clinical performance of the
Powerwand® midline catheter
Publication
Br J Nurs. 2021
DOI: 10.12968/bjon.2021.30.8.S10
Study location
United States
Study Length
4 months (September 2018 - December 2018)

Study protocol. In infants, the Powerwand was typically inserted in
the lower leg or upper arm, while in toddlers and
older children, it was placed in the forearm or upper
arm.

Study findings. Patients were spared an average of 12 vascular access attempts, during their hospitalization, when
Powerwand was used.

Study findings. On average, the use of these catheters prevented average 6.1 PVC reinsertions and 6.3 blood draw sticks per
patient. In terms of cost, each Powerwand catheter cost $170.25, compared to $32.55 per PVC. This resulted
in an overall cost saving of $2,892.45 due to the reduction in PVC use.
Study findings. Midline catheters are becoming more prevalent in both inpatient and outpatient settings.

Study findings. The Powerwand midline catheter offers a safe, durable, and cost-effective alternative to
CVCs and PVCs, reducing complications and improving vascular access outcomes across
patient populations.

24. Optimizing vascular-access device decision-making in the era of midline catheters. Values highlighted: Reduced Complications | Longer Dwell Time | Stability| Cost Effective
(Cawcutt KA et al. Infect Control Hosp Epidemiol. 2019)
Study author(s)
Cawcutt KA, Hankins RJ, Micheels TA,
et al.
Publication
Infect Control Hosp Epidemiol. 2019
DOI: 10.12968/bjon.2021.30.8.S10
Study design (level of evidence)
Narrative review (Level 6)
Study objective
To guide clinicians in selecting the most
appropriate vascular access device (VAD)
and to address risks, benefits, and
complications associated with various VADs.
Study location
United States
Study Length
NA
Study findings. Midlines are appropriate for medium-term therapy (typically up to 4 weeks).

Study findings. Midlines do not reach central veins, reducing risk of pneumothorax, cardiac arrhythmias, and central venous
stenosis.
Study findings. Vancomycin and other medications previously considered vesicants are increasingly safe via midline.
Study findings. Midline programs are associated with reduced CLABSI rates and cost.
Study findings. Mechanical complications (e.g., pain, edema, occlusion) occur at rates between 2.6%–11.5%.
Study findings. Thrombosis risk is generally lower than PICCs, especially in non-ICU settings.
Study findings. Patient satisfaction is improved by fewer needlesticks and lower complication rates.

Study findings. Midline catheters offer a safe, cost-effective alternative to central lines for medium-term
therapy, with fewer complications and strong support for broader use in clinical decision-
making.

25. Recommendations for the use of vascular access in the COVID-19 patients: an Italian perspective. Values highlighted: Reduced Complications | Longer Dwell Time | Stability| Cost Effective
(Pittiruti M et al. Crit Care. 2020)
Study author(s)
Pittiruti M, Pinelli F
Publication
Crit Care. 2020
DOI: 10.1186/s13054-020-02997-1
Study design (level of evidence)
Consensus recommendations (Level
6)
Study objective
To recommend safe and effective vascular
access strategies for COVID-19 patients.
Study location
Italy
Study Length
NA

Study findings. Midline catheters and mini-midlines are recommended for non-ICU COVID-19 patients over short peripheral
cannulas.
Study findings. Ultrasound-guided insertion is strongly recommended for midlines.
Study findings. No radiologic confirmation is needed for tip placement in midlines

Study findings. Emphasis on infection control, anticoagulation protocols, and operator safety during insertion and
maintenance.
